intro: Parastrobilanthes backeri, commonly known as the Khasi grass, is a perennial herb native to the northeastern regions of India. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tubular, two-lipped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
